It's worth noting that you can actually tell the difference between races by the size of the skull. Skull measurements are a real and valid thing used frequently in forensic anthropology and criminology, but the only thing is means is that some people have differently sized craniums. It has no bearing on intellect, potential, or anything that isn't pretty much cosmetic.

Charles Darwin: The Descent of Man. Chapter 7, "On the Races of Man"

"But the most weighty of all the arguments against treating the races
of man as distinct species, is that they graduate into each other,
independently in many cases, as far as we can judge, of their having
intercrossed. Man has been studied more carefully than any other
animal, and yet there is the greatest possible diversity amongst
capable judges whether he should be classed as a single species or
race, or as two (Virey), as three (Jacquinot), as four (Kant), five
(Blumenbach), six (Buffon), seven (Hunter), eight (Agassiz), eleven
(Pickering), fifteen (Bory de St-Vincent), sixteen (Desmoulins),
twenty-two (Morton), sixty (Crawfurd), or as sixty-three, according to
Burke. This diversity of judgment does not prove that the races ought
not to be ranked as species, but it shews that they graduate into each
other, and that it is hardly possible to discover clear distinctive
characters between them.

"Every naturalist who has had the misfortune to undertake the
description of a group of highly varying organisms, has encountered
cases (I speak after experience) precisely like that of man; and if of
a cautious disposition, he will end by uniting all the forms which
graduate into each other, under a single species; for he will say to
himself that he has no right to give names to objects which he
cannot define."

The classic definition of species is being able to produce offspring that are fertile. Separate species that are closely related enough that they can interbreed create a hybrid that is infertile (donkey+horse= mule for example.) Other definitions of species include other factors such as being a separate breeding population, separating by group traits and such.

The problem comes when people choose a definition of species that supports their desired conclusions. When you want to get famous for a fossil find, you want to make sure you call it a separate species (even though we know Neanderthals interbred with "our" species). When you want to try to separate yourself from "those" people over there but you can't get away with calling them a separate species, you call them a different race.

'Course the video talking about genetics has a bunch of people bringing up the scientifically dead idea of "race".

Here's a hint, you guys, biology doesn't consider race an actual scientific thing. Like, at all, the genetic differences between "races" are an incredibly small amount of genetic variation, not nearly enough to be used as an actual scientific distinction. There's more variation within "races" than between them. We just think there's more difference than there actually is because those few differences manifest as highly-visible physical differentiation, but genetically those are just a drop in the bucket.

Oh, and as for the numbskulls mentioning IQ, IQ has been shown to change depending on incredibly variable factors, like mood, the time of day or whether you take the test again, it's not a good marker of intelligence. Plus, it only really tests for the kind of intelligence found in academia, so if you're not given a similar background, obviously you won't score well there. Also IQ's been improving across the board for years now, and it's been improving for black and Hispanic people the fastest, suggesting the differential likely has more to do with access to education and upbringing than biology.

New human fossils found in North Africa, meaning that humans may have originated further North than we previously believed.

One hundred thousand years ago our ancient ancestors walked out of Africa for the first time.
They did not know what they would find, only that they had to become explorers if they were to survive.
They walked, ran, swam and paddled so far that after only a short while they had all but colonised the Earth.
But it came at a cost – over the tens of thousands of years that exploration took they forgot that once they were all brothers and sisters.
They forgot that they all came from the same place.
Time, the challenges and encounters faced along the way, and their new environments changed them. They adapted to the cold and to the heat of their new homes. To the resources and scarcities.
And after a time these now-disparate populations met once more, but since they had forgotten where they had all come from they thought themselves different.
That the shades of their skin or the shape of their bodies made them alien from each other.
And yet, under those physical changes, they were still African adventurers finding their way.
It took even the brightest minds centuries to realise this.
Even now we struggle to accept it as fact.
But the truth will one day win out.
Humanity is one tribe.
One tribe whose achievements inscribe the greatest story ever told.
The story of the Human Race.

the same science that told people there were superiors and inferiors is now telling people everyone is the same, and this is within three generations.

i have to admit that i can understand why some people are confused. this is essentially saying, "don't trust science, trust science." how does anyone know that what we're supposed to believe as "scientific" today won't be seen in three more generations as the same type of politically motivated bunk phrenology is understood to be today? maybe we're not all exactly alike. i can picture a few scenarios where there being real, fundamental, measurable, biological differences between different ethnicities of people and having those differences ignored in the name of "diversity science" could have devastating effects - notably in the areas of industrialized agriculture and medicine.

you can't make people healthy with food their bodies can't process and medicine that isn't made for their chemistry, so what if it turns out that in order to do those things, it is precisely our differences we must identify and attend to? what will "science" say then? there are still people who think different races are different species. how much harder is it going to be to get everybody fed when science starts saying "whoops, we were wrong. everyone really is different and has different needs."? it's been hard enough to get most people to treat everyone as more or less a human being. i don't know that civilization could stand the strain of genuine diversity at this point.
